{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3574170,"name":"Bill Kinahan","username":"kinahawi","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/d2c977/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T21:44:58.727Z","cooked":"

Is there a way to use the ProfiledPIDController and have it start at a non-zero velocity? We’re trying to use it for an auto approach to the reef after completing a path that finishes with a non-zero velocity. Is there an alternate controller that would be better suited to this?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T21:44:58.727Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":220,"readers_count":219,"score":104.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":497455,"topic_slug":"profiledpid-with-non-zero-starting-velocity","display_username":"Bill Kinahan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34177,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/profiledpid-with-non-zero-starting-velocity/497455/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3574278,"name":"Owen Busler","username":"Owen_Busler","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/owen_busler/{size}/7684_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T22:51:16.300Z","cooked":"

we’re doing something similar here, you can reset the profiled PID controller and specify the current position and current velocity. it will then continue to update the set point following your acceleration and velocity limits from the position and velocity specified. we have had a few oddities where you specify a current velocity and position, and then A goal position and velocity that are impossible to reach within your constraints, causes some weird behavior.

github.com

    2. 
          
  2.

    4.

    5.

    6.

    12.

    13.

    14.

    15.

  16. //init an OTF path to any point on field
    17.

    19.

    20. 
          
  20.     }
    21. 
          
  21.     Settings.xController.reset();
    22.

I see some teams use 3 regular PID controllers instead of the holonomic drive controller which typically is 2 PID controllers and one ProfiledPID controller. We use neither method. We adjust paths to actually complete properly (they aren’t proper paths - they complete correctly though.)

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-31T01:34:49.224Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":497455,"topic_slug":"profiledpid-with-non-zero-starting-velocity","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/profiledpid-with-non-zero-starting-velocity/497455/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601333,"name":"","username":"SM695","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sm695/{size}/224978_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T15:25:44.953Z","cooked":"

After watching some of your match videos, y’all have a really nice auto-align! I was reading through your logic for resetting the “dControllerAP” which from my understanding is just a ProfiledPIDController on distance to target pose and I wasn’t entirely clear on how it works.

Here are the methods I’m looking at:

    //when not APing we need to reset the PID controllers so they know where we are and can have smooth transitions 
    public void resetAPPIDControllers() {
        Settings.dControllerAP.reset(new State(Settings.getDistanceBetweenTwoPoses(apGoalPose, swerveDrive.getPose()), -getRobotVelopcity()));
        Settings.rControllerAP.reset(new State(0, 0));
    }

    public double getRobotVelopcity() {
        double velocityX = thisRobot.drivebase.swerveDrive.getFieldVelocity().vxMetersPerSecond;
        double velocityY = thisRobot.drivebase.swerveDrive.getFieldVelocity().vyMetersPerSecond;
        double velocity = Math.sqrt(velocityX * velocityX + velocityY * velocityY);

        return velocity;

    }

Here’s what I don’t really understand:
It looks like y’all are resetting the distance controller with your robot speed (not velocity), which doesn’t take into account the direction of the robot velocity. For example, there is no distinction if the robot began with an initial velocity directly towards the target, directly away from the target, or even perpendicular to the target. I was wondering if this was intentional (if so, why?) or has a noticable effect on your auto-align. I was going to try implementing one ProfiledPIDController on distance (as opposed to 1 controller on x and another one on y) and was thinking about how you might want to reset the velocity on the controller, and I figured it might make sense to reset it with just the component of velocity which points towards the target position. One drawback of this that I could see is that it doesn’t account for any initial robot velocity perpendicular to the target.

Thank you! This worked for us because we were using otf paths that ended around half a meter away from our goal pose so the direction was always facing the goal. All the robot needed to do was slide forward a little bit to reach it.
However, we didn’t really run into this problem, but if the robot is coming in at an angle, it won’t work, and having the angle to the target would be useful.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T22:51:55.223Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":68,"readers_count":67,"score":18.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497455,"topic_slug":"profiledpid-with-non-zero-starting-velocity","display_username":"Olivia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":60065,"username":"SM695","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sm695/{size}/224978_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75061,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Olivia"},"post_url":"/t/profiledpid-with-non-zero-starting-velocity/497455/7","custom_user_title":"Olivia","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602083,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T01:38:03.788Z","cooked":"
SM695:

reset it with just the component of velocity which points towards the target position

This is correct. This is what we were doing (mostly stolen from 6328’s drive to pose command):

ChassisSpeeds fieldVelocity = ChassisSpeeds.fromRobotRelativeSpeeds(parameters.currentChassisSpeed, parameters.currentPose.getRotation());
Translation2d linearFieldVelocity = new Translation2d(fieldVelocity.vxMetersPerSecond, fieldVelocity.vyMetersPerSecond);
double resetDistance = parameters.currentPose.getTranslation().getDistance(goalPose.getTranslation());
throttleController.reset(
        resetDistance,
        Math.min(
                0.0,
                -linearFieldVelocity
                        .rotateBy(goalPose.getTranslation()
                                .minus(parameters.currentPose.getTranslation())
                                .getAngle()
                                .unaryMinus())
                        .getX()),
        parameters.timestamp);
throttleController.setGoal(0);
